5.text: The dental technician receives two functional impressions,

7.text:
which are secured in the correct occlusal
height and centric position

11.text: by means of the intraoral registration of the Gnathometer M.

20.text: in the anterior region and note it down.

30.text: After that, carefully separate the functional impressions

33.text: and carefully remove the support pin registration plate.

43.text: The following reference points must be observed for the correct model orientation:

48.text: The incisive papilla and palatine raphe provide the anatomical midline.

55.text: Mark the highest elevation of the tuberosities on both sides.

59.text: This allows you to determine the dorsal centre.

65.text: Extend the midline to the edge of the model.

71.text: Mark the lowest point of the vestibulum.

74.text: It is situated approx. 5 mm away from the labial frenum.

84.text: In the lower jaw, mark the retromolar pad

86.text: and the path of the alveolar ridge.

92.text: Mark the occlusal plane in the area approx.

94.text: 5 mm below the dorsal end of the retromolar pad.

101.text: Transfer it to the model edge.

105.text: The horizontal guide supports the average‐value model orientation

108.text: of fully and partially edentate or edentulous models

112.text: within the Bonwill triangle of the articulator.

116.text: Set the symphysis fork of the horizontal guide

121.text: Make sure that the side wings are aligned

123.text: bilateral to the half of the retromolar pad.

127.text: The fork sits on the lowest point of the mucolabial fold,

138.text: Mount the horizontal guide in the articulator

140.text: with the help of the instrument carrier.

146.text: Mount the base plate in the articulator

148.text: and secure the mandibular model using dental plaster.

152.text: Wait until the plaster has set.

155.text: Then cautiously remove the horizontal guide

163.text: Cut back the functional impression of the lower jaw on the vestibular side.

172.text: Check whether it closely fits the model.

179.text: Position the mandibular model with the support pin

181.text:
in centric position on the upper bite
registration.

184.text: Combine the models until the mandibular model contacts the silicone key.

189.text: Transfer the esthetic midline marked by the clinician to the mandibular model.

195.text: If the models fit into the registration without any problem,

205.text: Mount the maxillary model in this position using the magnetic base block.

210.text: Articulation is done in the conventional manner

212.text: with or without a split cast system.

217.text: Precise and stable resin plates made of tray material

220.text: facilitate the try‐in and prevent deformation.

229.text: Ideally, use a hard wax with a high

232.text: softening point for setting‐up the teeth.

241.text: Determine the inter‐vestibular distance and note down

244.text:
the value measured on the edge of the
maxillary model

247.text: and half the value on the edge of the mandibular model.

251.text: In this way you determine the position of the occlusal plane in the anterior region.

258.text: Half the inter‐vestibular distance plus 2 mm overjet

261.text:
results in the length of the maxillary incisors in a
normal bite situation.

268.text: plus 7 to 9 mm indicates the labio‐palatal alignment

273.text: of the central incisors, the so‐called lip support.

277.text: Align the two central incisors mesially towards the midline.

282.text: The central incisors are set‐up perpendicular,

285.text:
the lateral incisors are set‐up slightly inclined towards
the mesial aspect.

291.text: Usually, the maxillary incisors point toward the lower mucolabial fold

299.text: in with the vertical anterior tooth arch.

302.text: The position of the canines is of decisive importance for the function

306.text:
and esthetic appearance of the
set‐up.

309.text: The symmetric positioning of the canines,

311.text: the most distinctive teeth in the maxillary anterior region, facilitates the set‐up.

317.text: The canines are again set‐up perpendicular along the longitudinal axis.

321.text: Ideally, the distal ridge runs parallel

323.text: to the sagittal course of the alveolar ridge.

327.text: After the set‐up of the maxillary anterior teeth,

329.text: they can be checked using the setting‐up template.

333.text: The symmetrical line system of the template

335.text:
enables the verification of the harmonious position of
the teeth.

340.text: This "lively" set‐up supports the natural effect of the dental reconstruction.

345.text: The extension of the longitudinal axis of the mandibular canine

349.text:
points between the maxillary lateral
incisor and the canine.

353.text: Basically, bilateral symmetry to the setting‐up template

357.text: has to be kept in mind during the set‐up,

359.text: in other words the average‐value orientation.

362.text: It is important to set‐up the canine out of contact,

365.text: which ensures reliable group guidance in the posterior region.

369.text: Position the first premolar in such a way

372.text: that a smooth transition to the canine is achieved.

376.text: This means that the distal slope of the incisal edge

379.text: is flush with the mesial rise of the first premolar.

384.text: Adjust the template for the posterior tooth set‐up,

387.text: for which the bottom side of the anterior part is aligned

389.text: according to the cusp tip of the mandibular canines.

393.text: In the posterior area, the underside of the template ends

397.text:
in the area of the distal thirds of the
retromolar pads.

400.text: With the setting‐up template, the curves of Wilson and Spee

406.text: This results in a bilateral standardized Monsen compensating curve

415.text: can be symmetrically aligned with the template on both sides.

420.text: Pound's line and the centre of the alveolar ridge

422.text: are reference points for the orientation of the

424.text: functional corridor for the posterior tooth set‐up.

427.text: In this way, the lingual and buccal limit

430.text: and the tatics are taken into consideration.

435.text: The posterior teeth have contacts with the template as follows:

443.text: The first premolar with buccal cusps

446.text: The second premolar with buccal and mesio‐lingual cusps

451.text: The first and second molar with mesio‐ and disto‐buccal

459.text: Check whether the teeth are correctly positioned within the functional corridor.

465.text: The line system of the template facilitates

467.text: the symmetrical set‐up of the posterior teeth.

471.text: Nevertheless, there is a certain range of variation.

478.text: The "Typ" teeth from Ivoclar Vivadent implement the concept by Dr Strack.

483.text: It is based on the simultaneous group contact

486.text: both on the working and balancing sides.

490.text: Remove the setting‐up template and mount the maxillary model.

495.text: Set‐up the posterior teeth of the upper jaw

497.text: in accordance with a normal bite situation

499.text: in a onetooth to two‐teeth relation to the lower jaw.

508.text: When the teeth are set‐up correctly,

510.text: the primary contacts in the centric position are located in the central fossae

515.text: as well as on the marginal ridges.

517.text: In the mandible, the "Typ" teeth are supported

520.text: by a secondary contact area on the buccal cusps.

526.text: If there is not enough space or for reasons of statics,

529.text: the maxillary second molar can be omitted.

534.text: set‐up the second molar in the mandible to support the cheeks.

539.text: As far as the mandibular anterior teeth are concerned,

542.text: in most cases only the incisal edges can be seen in the top view.

546.text: In order to achieve an esthetic appearance,

549.text:
interlock the anterior teeth and
grind in wear facets.

556.text: The overjet should be in the range of 0.5 to 1.0 mm.

561.text: Make sure that the maxillary anterior teeth are placed on the alveolar ridge cervically

566.text: and that the incisal area shows a slight inclination towards the labial

570.text: in a normal bite situation so that the orbicularis oris muscle can adapt.

576.text: To facilitate the final contouring, secure the teeth with hard wax.

580.text: For the remainder of the denture body,

582.text: use a more contouring‐friendly, slightly softer wax.

586.text: The following important points have to be considered in this context:

589.text: Basically, contour the gingiva in such a way

592.text: that it is easy to clean and has a lifelike appearance.

596.text: Too prominent contours such as balconies must be avoided.

602.text: the gingival margin tends to run the highest in the distal third.

608.text: in the mandible tends to be in the centre area.

611.text: Slightly outline the course of the root in a true‐to‐nature manner.

615.text: Create the corresponding freeway space for the labial and cheek frenulum.

620.text: Avoid small concave areas, as they can be difficult to clean by the patient.

626.text: Embrace tubera and trigona, as they assume

635.text: Give the vestibular parts of the lower denture

638.text: a concave design to accommodate muscle dynamics.

641.text: In this way, the cheeks and muscles can optimally adapt to the denture body.

649.text: The vestibular parts of the upper denture should be given a

652.text:
convex design – particularly in the
molar region.

657.text: This then supports the masseter muscle

659.text:
and minimizes the possibility of "cheek
biting".

663.text: The gingival design should correspond with

665.text: the completed work as closely as possible.

670.text: Use a synthetic hair brush to remove wax residue from the teeth.

674.text: Polish the wax to a high gloss using a foam polishing pad.

679.text: A polished surface is pleasant for the patient

681.text: and simplifies the completion of the denture later on.

686.text: As soon as the dentures have been completed in wax,

694.text: and the Immediate Side Shift movement in the articulator.

700.text: The protrusion angle should remain secured

702.text: at 30 degrees, according to average values.

706.text: Check the occlusal functions, starting from the centric position.

711.text: Check whether the bucco‐mesial surfaces of the upper premolars

715.text: slide over the bucco‐distal edges of the lower premolars on both sides.

721.text: The mesio‐palatal cusps of the upper molars

724.text: slide on the disto‐buccal cusps of the lower molars.

727.text: The disto‐buccal facets of the upper premolars

730.text: slide over the mesio‐buccal facets of the second premolar and the first molar.

739.text: Set‐up or grind in the anterior teeth in such a way

742.text: that they come into group contact with the posterior teeth.

748.text: Prevent a mere anterior/canine guidance in any case!
